titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Lucy Maynard Salmon Papers, 1818-1992 (bulk 1854-1933)

did.head: Collection Summary

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: Archives and Special Collections Library, Vassar College Libraries

did.abstract: The Lucy Maynard Salmon Collection includes the personal papers of Lucy Maynard Salmon along with two smaller collections of papers belonging to her mother, Maria Clara Maynard Salmon, and her brother, Pomeroy L. Salmon. The materials relate to her work as an historian and professor at Vassar College as well as her work with the suffrage movement and local political issues. There are also materials relating to her family, education and personal life. Formats include correspondence, manuscripts, printed material, clippings, minutes, reports, notes, and photographs.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Lucy Maynard Salmon, historian, was born in Fulton, NY, on 27 July 1853. After attending a local seminary, she entered the University of Michigan in 1872. Upon graduation she taught high school for five years, but tired of the monotony of small-town life and returned to Ann Arbor to earn her master's degree in modern European history, English, and American constitutional history. Following three unhappy years of teaching at Indiana State Normal School, she went to Bryn Mawr for graduate study in American history. In 1887 she became Vassar's first teacher of history and was made a full professor in 1889, remaining at Vassar for the rest of her career.

Modern history was a recent addition to the American college curriculum, and Miss Salmon was one of its most innovative teachers. Conducting her advanced classes as seminars, she encouraged students to do original research and to explore unconventional sources. Miss Salmon was instrumental in liberalizing Vassar's curriculum and administration. She stressed the importance of current affairs and the periodical press, and introduced classes on the newspaper and the use of historical materials, with particular emphasis on scholarly research techniques. Outside the history department she actively worked for a better library, fewer required courses, and greater influence of the faculty on the college administration.

Her publications, which included Domestic Service , The Newspaper and the Historian , and The Newspaper and Authority were expressive of her faith in democracy. Two books published posthumously, Why is History Rewritten? (1929) and Historical Material (1933), reflect her devotion to the "New History" of scholars like James Harvey Robinson. A pacifist and dedicated suffragist, Miss Salmon was a notable participant in local public affairs, in the American Historical Association, and in the Association of Collegiate Alumnae. She continued to be an active scholar and teacher until she suffered a fatal stroke in 1927. A biography, Apostle of Democracy: the Life of Lucy Maynard Salmon (1943), was written by her Vassar colleague, Louise Fargo Brown.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Lucy Maynard Salmon Collection includes the personal papers of Lucy Maynard Salmon along with two smaller collections of papers belonging to her mother, Maria Clara Maynard Salmon, and her brother, Pomeroy L. Salmon. Types of material represented in the collection include: incoming and outgoing correspondence; published and unpublished manuscripts; pamphlets, periodicals, news clippings (originals and photocopies), and other printed materials; diaries and journals; reminiscences and genealogies; and photographs.

A substantial portion of the Lucy Maynard Salmon Collection dates between 1887 and 1927, the years during which Lucy Maynard Salmon served on the Vassar College Faculty. Subjects covered by the collection include: the development of the history department at Vassar College; methods of teaching history; the use of original source materials in research; the women's suffrage movement; the University of Michigan; the Fulton Falley Seminary; home economics; domestic service; and other personal, family and profession issues.
There is also information about professional organizations such as the Association of Collegiate Alumnae, American Association of University Women, and the American Historical Association.

Correspondents include Caroline E. Page Salmon, Pomeroy Lyman Salmon, George Salmon, Lucy Ella Maynard Sloss, and other family members, 1859-1926; Henry Noble MacCracken, James Monroe Taylor, Louise Fargo Brown, Eloise Ellery, C. Mildred Thompson, and other Vassar associates, 1887-1927; Edith Rickert, Amelia MacDonald Cutler, Helena Grow Rottschaefer, and other Vassar students, 1890-1927; James Burrell Angell, Katharine Lee Bates, George Lincoln Burr, Alice Freeman Palmer, M. Carey Thomas, Lelia Y. Burt, H.V. Clulow, Rachel Larrabee, Gertrude H. Mason, and other educational and political contemporaries, 1870-1927; Adelaide Underhill, Vassar College Librarian with whom Salmon shared a house, 1894-1927, and condolence letters to Underhill on Salmon's death, 1927-1931; and round-robin letters from student social groups at the University of Michigan, "Q. Ceekers," and at Bryn Mawr, "The Learned Six," 1874-1893.

Papers of her mother, Maria Clara Maynard Salmon, include class notes, circa 1834, diaries and account books, 1840-1863, and correspondence with Miranda Smith Belden, George Salmon, James B. Maynard, Frederick W. Lyman, and Lucy Piper Maynard, 1831-1861.

Papers of her brother, Pomeroy Lyman Salmon, include correspondence with family and friends, primarily Pomeroy's parents, George Salmon and Maria Clara Maynard Salmon, and his son, Maynard Hubbard Salmon, as well as family records and documents, financial records, memorabilia, and published ephemera.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research according to the regulations of the Vassar College Archives and Special Collections Library without any additional restrictions.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Permission to quote (publish) from unpublished or previously published material must be obtained as described in the regulations of the Vassar College Archives and Special Collections Library.

odd.head: Encoding Information
odd.p: Original encoding by Elizabeth Clarke, 2007. Updated by Mark Seidl, 2019. Updated by Emma Gronbeck, June 2023.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Original processing date unknown. Reprocessed circa 1984 and again in January 2000. Updated August 2007. Pomeroy L. Salmon series added, June 2023.
Boxes 42-64 are processed and described only at the box level.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Gift of the Estate of Lucy Maynard Salmon and contributions by relatives and friends, circa 1936.
Two albums of postcards from Sweden and Norway were transferred from the Vassar College History Department, 2012. [M2012-010]
One letter by Lucy Maynard Salmon was purchased from John Wilson Manuscripts, Ltd., 2019. [M2019-016]
Pomeroy L. Salmon addition was the gift of Jeffrey Salmon, 2023. [M2023-033]

altformavail.head: Other Formats
altformavail.p: Some items from the Salmon Papers are available electronically via the Vassar College Digital Library. The items were digitized as part a Hudson River Valley Heritage exhibit, Women of the Hudson Valley.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Lucy Maynard Salmon Papers, Archives and Special Collections Library, Vassar College Libraries.

scopecontent.p: This series contains letters from Lucy Maynard Salmon to others, arranged alphabetically.

did.unittitle: b. Vassar College Faculty, Trustees, and Administrators
c. Vassar College Students and Alumnae

scopecontent.p: This subseries includes all round-robin letters written by "Q. Ceekers" and "The Learned Six," social groups to which Lucy Maynard Salmon belonged at University of Michigan and Bryn Mawr, respectively.
This series contains letters to Lucy Maynard Salmon from others, arranged alphabetically.

did.unittitle: b. Vassar College Faculty, Trustees, and Administrators
c. Vassar College Students and Alumnae
Series III. Correspondence — To and From Others,

scopecontent.p: This series contains letters to and from family members, friends, colleagues, and acquaintances of Lucy Maynard Salmon to others.
This series consists of notes, drafts, and published copies of Lucy Maynard Salmon's writings, as well as related correspondence.

This series contains Lucy Maynard Salmon's personal journal; personal ephemera such as certificates; family documents and records; and printed and published materials about Salmon and her extended family.
This series consists of photographs of Lucy Maynard Salmon and her family, as well as some photographs of assorted other subjects.

This series contains records of Lucy Maynard Salmon's time at Vassar College as a member of the faculty. Includes committee correspondence and reports; correspondence with other faculty and administrators; correspondence with alumnae; materials concerning the Lucy Maynard Salmon Fund for Research; financial records of purchases made for the college library; course outlines and examinations; annual reports; and Vassar College publications.

did.unittitle: Series VIII. Research and Subject Files,

scopecontent.p: This series consists of Lucy Maynard Salmon's collected files on various topics and research subjects. Also includes correspondence with various organizations and individuals related to file subjects.

This series contains the papers of Lucy Maynard Salmon's mother, Maria Clara Maynard Salmon. Includes Maria Clara Maynard's personal diaries, correspondence, and class notes and ephemera from her education at Ipswich Female Seminary.

Letters written to Maria Clara Maynard Salmon are filed alphabetically by author. Multiple letters by a single author are arranged chronologically within this alphabetical arrangement. Letters written by Maria Clara Maynard Salmon are arranged in an alphabetical sequence according to the name of the recipient. Multiple letters to a single recipient are further arranged according to chronology.
This series includes assorted other materials, including memorabilia and realia; notes and writings; published materials; legal documents; and photographs.

did.unittitle: Series XI. Pomeroy L. Salmon Papers

scopecontent.p: This series contains the papers of Lucy Maynard Salmon's brother, Pomeroy Lyman Salmon. Includes correspondence with family and friends, primarily Pomeroy's parents, George Salmon and Maria Clara Maynard Salmon, and his son, Maynard Hubbard Salmon. The letters were collected by Maynard Hubbard Salmon and many include notes in his hand. Other materials include family records and documents, financial records, memorabilia, and published ephemera.

Includes clippings, notes on itinerary, address book, letters of introduction, letters from Charles Homer Haskins, Williston Hough, Michael Ernest Sadler, Charles Seignobos, and Andrew D. White; also a statement of household expenses in London, 1898. (See also 47.1-.3: Trips to Europe.),
Proposed book on History in the Schools. Four letters from Nicholas Murray Butler, 1898, and 2 letters and an agreement with the Macmillan Co.,
A collection of pamphlets on the teaching of history,

College entrance requirements for history. Includes copy of an article by Lucy Maynard Salmon published in The Academy, May 1888; a typescript, "Discussion of Professor H. Morse Stephens' Paper 'Shall Historical Studies Be a Necessary Part of College Entrance Requirements?'", 1896; correspondence regarding it, including letters from James R. Rhoads and Moses Coit Tyler; later letters from Mary G. Barnes, William MacDonald, and Adam Leroy Jones; a statement of principles; and clippings.

Association of History Teachers of the Middle States and Maryland. Lucy Maynard Salmon was the first president of the organization; the folder includes historical information, programs, and correspondence,

New York City Board of Education examination for teachers. A letter from William Maxwell, Superintendent, 1901, and information about license requirements. Report of the Public Education Association, 1900.
History Teacher's Magazine. A letter from James Franklin Jameson and letters from the editor, Albert E. McKinley.
Democracy in Education. Includes a manuscript by Lucy Maynard Salmon.
Women’s Education. Includes correspondence, with a copy of one reply by Lucy Maynard Salmon; and clippings.
Western Association of Collegiate Alumnae. Information about organization and correspondence,
Association of Collegiate Alumnae. Data about organization.
Association of Collegiate Alumnae. Correspondence, including letters from Herbert B. Adams, Alice Freeman Palmer, Marion Talbot, and M. Carey Thomas,
American Association of University Women. Lucy Maynard Salmon certificate of life membership and information about the organization.

Association of Colleges and Preparatory Schools of the Middle States and Maryland. Includes article by Lucy Maynard Salmon, "The Encroachments of the Secondary Schools on the College Curriculum" (1906), and a convention program in which she participated (1902).
American Association of University Professors. Information about the organization, reports, and correspondence,
Academic freedom. Mounted newspaper clippings and articles,

Education in France — Collection of documents and pamphlets relating to education,

Wilcox, Alice Wilson (VC 1894). Outline of Rhode Island Historical Associations, Landmarks and Documents,
Interest in home economics. General. Includes announcements of lectures, correspondence 1888-1916, reports, and clippings.

Domestic service correspondence. Replies to a questionnaire sent out by the Vassar History Department, 1888-1890, including a copy of the questionnaire, correspondence with John B. Clark and Richard T. Ely relating to it; and charts tabulating information for towns throughout the country.
Press notices of lectures and articles on domestic service, 1891-1893, and letters from Ellen Battelle Dietrick (?), 1889, and Florence Kelley, 1901.

Domestic Service , NY: Macmillan, 1897 (2d ed. 1901). Correspondence with Macmillan Co., including contract, review, criticisms, sales, and a box of clippings. Includes letters from Elizabeth Converse and Marion Talbot.
Correspondence with W.D.P. Bliss relating to article on "Domestic Service" for the Encyclopedia of Social Reform,

Household Research. Includes reports and copies of the bulletin of the Intermunicipal Committee on Household Research, and information and correspondence about the New York Association for Household Research.
Progress in the Household (Boston: Houghton Mifflin, 1906). Correspondence and reviews.
Miscellaneous notes and clippings relating to domestic service.
Domestic service in Germany. Lucy Maynard Salmon notes.
Clippings Box, labeled box 10, stored in back of folders in box 49
Publications relating to domestic service, including a "Bibliography of Domestic Economy" ( State Library Bulletin, Bibliography no. 22, June 1990, University of the State of New York).
Women's Educational and Industrial Union Reports,
Announcements and reports of Woman's Work Exchanges,
Announcements and reports of Women’s Work Exchanges (including U.S. and Germany),
Letters and clippings from Angelina Blackinton Sturgis Thurber to Mrs. J. Manchester Haynes concerning domestic service,
News clippings regarding Lucy Salmon and laundry and other articles referring to laundry
Correspondence to and from laundry establishments regarding the acquisition of laundry lists

Interest in the newspaper field. General. A file of correspondence, 1915-1927, including a letter about Lucy Maynard Salmon article on "Censorship" in the 13th edition of the Encylopaedia Britannica , 1926, and bibliographies.
Correspondence and material re: The Ulster County Gazette

Correspondence regarding The Newspaper and Authority, N.Y.: Oxford, 1923; The Newspaper and the Historian , NY: Oxford, 1923; and "The Newspaper and Research," American Journal of Sociology , XXXII, pp. 217-218 (September 1926).
Reviews and clippings regarding the preceding publications.
American Civic Association. Correspondence, 1910-1916, leaflets, and also a publication of the Massachusetts Civic League.
Civil Liberties. Correspondence with the American Civil Liberties Union, and NY Assembly correspondence relating to the Lusk bills(1920).
Civil Service Reform. Announcements of programs including Lucy Maynard Salmon; correspondence, 1901-1909; and publications.
Correspondence and clippings regarding History of the Appointing Power of the President , American Historical Association, 1886, and the Macmillan contract for a revised edition, 1901.
Interest in civic welfare, Poughkeepsie. Correspondence, 1907-1916, leaflets, 5 manuscript items, notes, contributions to newspapers (1923) urging support for the local library, and clippings.
Collection of mounted clippings relating to Commission government in Poughkeepsie,

Woman Suffrage. Includes Lucy Maynard Salmon manuscript; correspondence including letters from Harriot Stanton Blatch, Carrie Chapman Catt, Alice Paul, Anna Howard Shaw, Doris Stevens, and M. Carey Thomas; clippings
Woman Suffrage. Certificate of membership as an honorary regent of the Volunteer League of the National American Woman Suffrage Association.
American Historical Association. Information on organization, programs, and correspondence,
Daughters of the American Revolution and National Society of Colonial Dames. Programs, yearbooks, and clippings.
New York State Historical Association. Invitation to deliver annual address,
Hall of Fame Elector. Constitution; rules for elections; and correspondence,
The Searchlight . 3 letters regarding subscription and financial difficulties,
Notes and ephemera concerning the 1904 presidential election,
"List of References Relative to New York Manors," prepared by Victor H. Paltsits,

Guest book used at 263 Mill Street
